raw_text:
Queen recruit singer for new tour
 
 The remaining members of rock band Queen are to go on tour next year with former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers taking Freddie Mercury's place.
 
 Guitarist Brian May has said he expects to be on the road with Rodgers and drummer Roger Taylor from April. May said: "Suddenly the Queen Phoenix is rising again from the ashes and will take precedence over... our lives." Queen have played with many different singers since Mercury's death in 1991 but have reportedly not toured. May performed with Rodgers at a concert to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster guitar in London in September.
 
 "We were both so amazed at the chemistry that was going on in [Free hit] All Right Now, that suddenly it seems blindingly obvious that there was 'something happening here,'" May wrote on his website. They teamed up again for a concert to mark their induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame, and were joined by Taylor. "The show went so incredibly well from our point of view, and we got so many rave reactions from out there, we decided almost then and there that we would look at a tour together," May wrote.
 
 Queen went to number one in 2000 with a version of We Will Rock You sung by boy band 5ive and they have also played with Robbie Williams, Will Young and Bob Geldof. Queen bassist John Deacon has currently retired from the stage. Rodgers was singer with early 1970s rockers Free, who had a global hit with All Right Now, before forming Bad Company, a successful "supergroup" with members of King Crimson and Mott the Hoople. He has also been in The Firm with Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page and The Law with The Small Faces and The Who drummer Kenny Jones.

May had previously performed with Rodgers at a Fender Stratocaster induction concert in London.

"We were both so amazed at the chemistry that was going on in [Free hit] All Right Now, that suddenly it seems blindingly obvious that there was 'something happening here,'" said Brian May, Queen's lead guitarist and one of their most popular members.
They teamed up again for a concert to mark their induction into the UK Music Hall of Fame, and were joined by Paul Taylor from the rock band 50 Cent.

The show went so incredibly well from our point of view, and we got so many rave reactions from out there, we decided almost then and there that we would look at a tour together," said Queen bassist John Deacon.
"Queen have also played with early 1970s rockers Free, who had a global hit with All Right Now before forming Bad Company, a successful 'supergroup' with members of King Crimson and Mott the Hoople."
The band has also been in The Firm with Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page and The Law with The Small Faces and The Who drummer Kenny Jones.

tinydolphin:1.1b: Queen have announced that they will be taking former Free and Bad Company singer Paul Rodgers on tour to replace Freddie Mercury, who passed away in 1991.
The band's current members—guitarist Brian May, drummer Roger Taylor, and lead vocalist David Gilmore—will be joined by Rodgers for the new tour which is expected to take place in April 2022.

The remaining members of Queen, including guitarist-bassist John Deacon, have not played together since Mercury's death but are excited about the prospect of taking the stage again with someone who knows and loves the music they created together.
May wrote on his website that he was amazed at the chemistry that seemed to be "blindingly obvious" during a recent concert to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Fender Stratocaster guitars.
The band will induct themselves into the UK Music Hall of Fame and perform together for the first time in over 20 years at a concert celebrating their induction.
They will also be joined by Robbie Williams, Will Young, and Bob Geldof for a performance of We Will Rock You.
The show was an incredible success for Queen, who have played with some significant acts over the years.
Queen's bassist John Deacon has retired from performing, but has had an illustrious career in the music industry, both as a solo artist and with his current bandmates.
Deacon played drums on some of Queen's most popular songs, including the iconic song, "We Will Rock You."

####Summary: Queen and Paul Rodgers to form new supergroup for tour after playing together in the past.
Guitarist Brian May expects to be on the road with them from April.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Queen, the iconic rock band, is planning a tour for next year with Paul Rodgers as their lead singer, filling the void left by the late Freddie Mercury.
Guitarist Brian May and drummer Roger Taylor are expected to join the tour from April.
This marks the first time Queen will tour since Mercury's death in 1991.

May and Rodgers previously collaborated on concerts celebrating the Fender Stratocaster anniversary and Queen's UK Music Hall of Fame induction, showcasing strong on-stage chemistry that led to their decision to tour together.

Paul Rodgers, known for his tenure with Free and later Bad Company, has a diverse musical background, having also performed with Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page, The Small Faces, and The Who drummer Kenny Jones in various bands like The Firm and The Law.
Queen bassist John Deacon is currently retired from live performances.
Since 2000, the band has had a unique collaboration with boy band 5ive for "We Will Rock You," and has also performed with Robbie Williams, Will Young, and Bob Geldof.
